{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3327921,"name":"","username":"sciln24","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/6f9a4e/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-08T17:58:13.977Z","cooked":"

Hi. We’ve been experiencing a problem where every time we release a button on our xbox controller the robot code crashes. This happens in teleop, autonomous, and also disabled mode in the Driver Station. We know that the problem does not come from the button bindings in our robotContainer.py file as we’ve commented out those lines and the problem still persists. Here is the error we receive in the terminal:

command.schedule()
AttributeError: ‘function’ object has no attribute ‘schedule’

We don’t use this line in any files in our code.
Here is our code: GitHub - Team4169/Swerve2024: Git Repo for the 2023 - 2024 season

Does anyone know how to fix this? Any help would be greatly appreciated!

Is there any more to the error message? Anything that says what file/line the error is occuring at? Or can you tell us what button you press that triggers the error?

Do you have any conflicting button-related commands? If the trigger is making the robot try to do two things at once, that could cause a crash.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-03-08T18:09:32.647Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":69,"readers_count":68,"score":18.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":457919,"topic_slug":"robot-code-crashes-on-button-press","display_username":"Scarlett Saam","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64811,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"she/her | HOS | 4131"},"post_url":"/t/robot-code-crashes-on-button-press/457919/3","custom_user_title":"she/her | HOS | 4131","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3327990,"name":"","username":"sciln24","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/6f9a4e/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-08T19:19:56.704Z","cooked":"

This is the full error:
File “C:\Users\paul_\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python311\Lib\site-packages\commands2\button\trigger.py”, line 120, in _
command.schedule()
^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
AttributeError: ‘function’ object has no attribute ‘schedule’

Locals at innermost frame:

{ ‘command’: <function RobotContainer.configureButtonBindings.. at 0x0000015D1925…
‘pressed’: False,
‘self’: <commands2.button.joystickbutton.JoystickButton object at 0x0000015D1435F650>,
‘state’: namespace(pressed_last=True)}

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-03-08T19:19:56.704Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":53,"readers_count":52,"score":15.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":457919,"topic_slug":"robot-code-crashes-on-button-press","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":9105,"username":"Fletch1373","name":"Fletch","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":56900,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/robot-code-crashes-on-button-press/457919/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3327991,"name":"Chris Gerth","username":"gerthworm","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/gerthworm/{size}/268658_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-08T19:19:59.592Z","cooked":"

Keep looking around that error, I think there should be more - the traceback has more info about how you got there, and what led that line of code to be executed.

Most likely, command ended up being a reference to a function, rather than the return value of the function. This can happen if you forget the () when attempting to call a function.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-03-08T19:20:32.336Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":49,"readers_count":48,"score":9.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":457919,"topic_slug":"robot-code-crashes-on-button-press","display_username":"Chris Gerth","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://realpython.com/python-traceback/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Understanding the Python Traceback – Real Python","clicks":1}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24617,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/robot-code-crashes-on-button-press/457919/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3327993,"name":"Dustin Spicuzza","username":"virtuald","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/virtuald/{size}/65268_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-08T19:21:33.922Z","cooked":"

It is likely that the error is exactly what the error message says:

‘function’ object has no attribute ‘schedule’

That means that ‘command’ is a function, and is not whatever the code thought it should be (in this case, likely a Command). Functions do not have a ‘schedule’ attribute, so this makes sense.

If the error is occurring inside of the command framework code, that means you passed in a function where it was expecting a command. Look at the stack trace and determine where you messed up, and then don’t do that.

If you’re using vscode, I recommend turning on the basic type checking mode of pyright, it helps catch errors like this by highlighting them with a red squiggly.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-03-08T19:21:33.922Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":50,"readers_count":49,"score":10.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":457919,"topic_slug":"robot-code-crashes-on-button-press","display_username":"Dustin Spicuzza","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.emmanuelgautier.com/blog/enable-vscode-python-type-checking","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"How to enable Python type checking in VSCode","clicks":1}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":11063,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"RobotPy Guy, WPILib Developer"},"post_url":"/t/robot-code-crashes-on-button-press/457919/6","custom_user_title":"RobotPy Guy, WPILib Developer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3328017,"name":"NewtonCrosby","username":"NewtonCrosby","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/ed8c4c/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-08T19:44:13.978Z","cooked":"

A quick look at your button bindings and none of your commands seem to be passing subsystems as requirements, which should be a thing that needs to happen as well.

So I’d agree you probably have some things in your code that a type checker might be able to find for you.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":9,"updated_at":"2024-03-08T19:44:13.978Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":40,"readers_count":39,"score":8.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":457919,"topic_slug":"robot-code-crashes-on-button-press","display_username":"NewtonCrosby","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31346,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/robot-code-crashes-on-button-press/457919/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3328034,"name":"","username":"sciln24","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/6f9a4e/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-08T19:59:11.693Z","cooked":"

Thank you everyone for your input. We were able to solve the problem, as we had forgotten to input an InstantCommand in the onFalse of our button bindings, which fixed the error.
